headline: LiveTransfer news LIVE: Man Utd plan £34m bid, Liverpool confirm loan, Arsenal near THIRD move
body: Just days after Liverpool smashed the British transfer record with a deal for Florian Wirtz, they confirmed the £40million capture of Milos Kerkez. And they might not be done yet.

A striker - potentially Hugo Ekitike - could be still to follow at Anfield and there is some interest in Marc Guehi. That does mean a potential exit for Darwin Nunez and some uncertainty in the backline however.

Arsenal aren't wasting time either however. Deals for Christian Norgaard and Kepa Arrizabalaga are now agreed but there is still no news on a deal for Benjamin Sesko or Viktor Gyokeres, as they finally look to land a striker.

Manchester United are closing in on a frontman in the form of Bryan Mbeumo. That's bad news for Tottenham, who will have to look elsewhere to bolster Thomas Frank's squad. Eberechi Eze is in their thoughts but a deal does not look to come without competition.
Plenty more deals are in the works and some other big ones are bound to be bubbling along under the radar. So stick with us for all the latest transfer news as it breaks right down below...
Keith Andrews is officially Brentford's new head coach.
Andrews will replace Thomas Frank, who left the Bees to join Tottenham earlier this month.

Manchester United are hopeful of agreeing a deal for Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo in time for him to start pre-season with them. United submitted a second bid for Mbeumo, understood to be £55million, with the delay in concluding the deal down to agreeing the add-ons involved.

Everton could confirm a new deal for Jarrad Branthwaite as soon as next week as they look to tie down the central defender. The young star has seen links to Tottenham and Chelsea after Manchester United's pursuit was turned down last summer.

Harvey Elliott is likely to have no shortage of suitors this summer should he leave Liverpool with Brighton, West Ham and RB Leipzig of the Bundesliga all courting him following his heroics at the U21 European Championship finals.
Burnley have confirmed the signing of goalkeeper Max Weiss from Karlsruher on a four-year deal. A potential sign an exit for James Trafford is coming.
The Clarets are paying a fee of around £4.2m (€5m) for the 21-year-old.

Sunderland are eyeing a former Chlesea and PSF goalkeeper Marcin Bulka, per reports. The 25-year-old played times for Nice last term and the Premier League's newest side are interested in securing his services.
New York Red Bulls are said to be in talks over a move for RB Leipzig's Timo Werner. Werner is surplus to requirements in Germany after returning from loan spells with Spurs.
According to The Athletic, both clubs are optimistic they will strike a deal.
Werner is reported to be keen on a move to New York, and discussions are said to have been ongoing for months.
Burnley have confirmed striker Ashley Barnes,35, has signed a new one-year deal at Turf Moor as the club return to the Premier League.
Barnes, who has made more than 300 appearances for the Clarets, is said to have been an integral figure within the dressing room in the second half of last season.
After penning a his new deal, Barnes said: "I'm absolutely delighted to be back and re-join the Club for a third time now!
"I have unfinished business, I'm not done yet and I'm here to challenge for a place in the squad, as well as helping everyone out and being in that environment around the changing room.

"I can bring a lot of knowledge and experience to the new lads and younger players. There's a few of us that have been in the Premier League before and a few that are new to it, it's about having that balance in the team and I have to use my influence on and off the pitch to help where I can."
Ruud van Nistelrooy's Leicester exit has finally been confirmed following the Foxes' relegation.
The club have confirmed the Dutchman's departure by mutual consent.
Tom Heaton has signed a one-year contract at Manchester United, just days before his time with the club was set to end.
Heaton said: "I am extremely proud to continue to represent Manchester United. As a group, we are all really excited for the season ahead.
“I am ready to support the team in every capacity as we prepare to get back to challenging for the biggest honours.”
Newcastle have no plans to sign Marcus Rashford and are instead prioritising a former Manchester United team-mate of his, per reports.
Rashford, 27, is searching for a new side and despite claims of Newcastle considering a deal, Howe wants to sign ex-United winger Anthony Elanga, now of Nottingham Forest.
Cristiano Ronaldo will earn a whopping £492million over two years after signing his new deal with Al-Nassr and has landed an ownership stake in the club.
There's no shortage of perks for the Portugal superstar.
LAFC are mulling over an approach to sign Ange Postecoglou, according to BBC Sport.
Steve Cherundolo, their current head coach is to depart at the end of the season as he looks to move back to Germany, meaning the side are keeping an eye out for a new boss.
And Postecoglou is under consideration after being made available following his sacking by Tottenham.
Arsenal and Atletico Madrid are considering approaches for Inter Milan defender Carlos Augusto, per reports in Italy.
Arsenal sporting director Andrea Berta is said to be driving the possibility, with Atletico's interest said to reach as far back as the director's time with the La Liga side.
Augusto is currently competing in the Club World Cup with Inter.
Burnley confirmed that Alex Tuanzebe will join the club when his Ipswich contract expires in a matter of days. The former Manchester United defender is the Clarets' third signing.
Tuanzebe said: “I’m delighted to be here. It became a very simple decision after speaking to the manager and the message was very clear, precise and straight to the point.
“It’s a new chapter for me, back in the vicinity of Manchester and home and I’m ready to continue my journey now at Burnley.”

Bryan Mbeumo and Eberechi Eze are driving transfer interest this summer but there are too many sides for everyone to leave satisfied. Arsenal, Spurs and Manchester United will hope they are not the team left disappointed.

Newcastle are in advanced talks over the signing of Joao Pedro from Brighton. Chronicle Live report the Magpies are keen to get a deal over the line and have made it clear to the Seagulls that they are serious.
Brighton value Pedro close to £60m.

Liverpoolhave opened talks with Crystal Palace over a potential deal for Marc Guehi. The defender has been linked with a number of clubs as he enters the final year of his contract. Anfield is said to be the 24-year-old's preference amid the communication, reported by Teamtalk, that has taken place.
It has previously been said Arne Slot's side do not want to overpay however, with the Eagles staunch in their negotiations and having competition to rely upon.

Napoli and Juventus are both willing to pay Manchester United £25m for Jadon Sancho's services this summer. The Italian duo however are less keen on meeting the winger's £250,000 weekly wages, per Metro.
Can't say that is an unfair stance to take.

Cristian Romero's future Tottenham future has appeared uncertain this summer amid interest from Atletico Madrid. Daniel Levy is not set to budge easily however and plans to remain firm on his valuation of the central defender.
That means the La Liga side will be forced to stump up more than £60m.

Reports in Italy claim Manchester United are preparing an offer for Atalanta goalkeeper Marco Carnesecchi and are willing to offer €40m (£34m). That is a figure said to be short of the Serie A side's desired asking price, as they want nearer €40m (£43m), though add-ons could bridge some of that gap.

Jamie Gittens missed Borussia Dortmund's 1-0 win over Ulsan at the Club World Cup on Wednesday, but despite Gittens already agreeing personal terms and a deal reportedly close to being finalised, that had nothing to do with it...
Not according to Niko Kovac anyway.

And Gittens' absence from the Dortmund squad as they defeated Ulsan in Cincinnati fuelled suggestions that the move is all but done. However, Dortmund boss Niko Kovac insisted ahead of the game that Gittens only missed the game through illness.

The United star appeared to make it clear he wanted to move outside of the Premier League, with Barcelona his preferred destination. No deal has arrived however and now it appears another club will try their luck. It has been suggested Newcastle are making 'serious moves' for the forward.
The Magpies can offer Champions League football.

Brentford captain Christian Norgaard is on the verge of joining Arsenal after the midfielder was given the green light to undergo a medical. The Gunners could continue a success period after tying down Myles Lewis-Skelly to a new deal.
Latest Arsenal news.

Milos Kerekez wasn't the only deal Liverpool announced yesterday as the Reds squad continues to take shape. A new contract and a loan deal was also arranged. Oh, and Alexander Isak won't come cheap, who'd have thoought?
Latest Liverpool news.
We're back again! Thanks for joining us for another day of transfer news and rumours.
We'll keep you up to date with all of the goings on from around the Premier League as they day goes on. Stick around!
That's all we've got time for today, folks. But join us again tomorrow for all the latest breaking transfer news.
More on Arsenal's interest in Eberechi Eze.
The Sun are reporting that Andrea Berta, the Gunners' sporting director, has already held talks with the player's representatives.
Tottenham are also interested in the Crystal Palace star, who has a £68million buy-out clause in his deal.
Robbie Savage is closing in on being appointed as Forest Green Rovers manager after the eco-warriors parted company with Steve Cotterill.

Savage won promotion to the National League North in his first season as a head coach, at the age of 50, with born-again Macclesfield last season, smashing every club record for points, goals, clean sheets and wins.
The former Wales international, who captained four Premier League clubs, is believed to have turned down two offers from clubs at least two divisions higher than the Silkmen last year.
Newcastle are planning for an ambitious triple transfer swoop, but have now seen bids rejected for their top three targets.
Nottingham Forest turned down their opening offer for Anthony Elanga, with City Ground bosses adamant over their £60m valuation.
And, according to the Times, they have also seen offers for Burnley's James Trafford AND Brighton forward Joao Pedro rebuffed.
It is reported an offer of £25m was lodged for goalkeeper Trafford, while £50m wasn't enough for the Seagulls and Pedro.
It now remains to be seen whether the Magpies will go back in for their big targets as Eddie Howe hopes for more firepower for their Champions League campaign.

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Jadon Sancho talks held as Chelsea drop summer hintVIDEO
body: Manchester United are undergoing a major rebuild under Ruben Amorim this summer after enduring their worst ever Premier League campaign. United finished 15th last season and also failed to qualify for the Champions League after losing to Tottenham in the Europa League final.

The likes of Jonny Evans, Christian Eriksen and Victor Lindelof have all left the club on free transfers, while Jadon Sancho, Marcus Rashford, Alejandro Garnacho, Antony and Tyrell Malacia are expected to be sold.
United have already forked out £62.5million to sign Matheus Cunha from Wolves and they are also working on a deal for Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo, having lodged an improved bid worth more than £60m.
Manchester United have reportedly held talks with Juventus over a deal for Jadon Sancho, with Fenerbahce also interested in the winger.

According to reports from Italy, Juventus were keen to find out how feasible a move for Sancho is and club chiefs had a video call with United on Wednesday to discuss a deal. Juventus are keen to sign a new winger, with both Timothy Weah and Samuel Mbangula expected to leave.

However, reports from Turkey have claimed that Sancho has agreed personal terms with Fenerbahce. They are said to be willing to pay Sancho €10m (£8.5m) per year, while United have set a price tag of around €20m (£17m).
Chelsea boss Enzo Maresca has opened the door for Christopher Nkunku to leave the club this summer, with Manchester United said to be interested in the forward.

Nkunku has struggled for regular gametime since joining the Blues from RB Leipzig two years ago and when asked about the player's future, Maresca said: "If Christo is here with us, it is because we think he can help us and he can be with us even next season. But as you said, there are many speculations, not just about Christo, about many players.

"And then if something is going to happen, I don't know because we said many times when the transfer window is open, anything can happen in terms of players that can arrive or players that can leave."
According to the Guardian, Barcelona are interested in signing Marcus Rashford on loan this summer.

The forward is expected to leave Manchester United this summer and has publicly teased a move to Barcelona. The report states that United will want a fee-paying loan, but the Red Devils may have to take a hit on his wages.
Rashford is among their highest earners, taking home a reported £370,000-a-week, and it is claimed United 'may be forced to accept' a deal that involves Barcelona only paying a portion of his wages.
Sky will show at least 215 live Premier League games next season, an increase of up to 100 more.

headline: Man Utd could deny Marcus Rashford's dream transfer as club set out conditions
body: Marcus Rashford could be about to find that his wishes and those of Manchester United are not aligned as a dream move to Barcelona becomes a possibility. Both United and Rashford are on the same page over his departure from the club in the summer transfer window, but the nature of that exit is where the sticking point lies.

Rashford has made it clear that he is keen to join Barcelona ever since concluding a long spell at Aston Villa. While his brief loan spell at Villa ended in injury, Rashford still managed to revitalise his career with four goals and six assists in 17 appearances.

That suited United, who have made it clear that Rashford does not have a future at his boyhood club after a falling out with Ruben Amorim. The 27-year-old has his heart set on a move to Barcelona – and his representatives held talks with the club in late May over the potential move.

However, there are a few difficulties that must be overcome if Rashford is to get his move to Barca. First of all, his £325,000-a-week wages at United, where he is under contract until June 2028, are too steep for Barcelona, who have struggled with La Liga’s financial rules in recent years.

Then there was Barca’s move for Athletic Bilbao winger Nico Williams, who now looks likely to arrive in a £50million move this summer. Williams – and Barca’s stand-out player last season, Raphinha – play on the left of attack, which is Rashford’s best position.

Barca boss Hansi Flick reportedly believes that, rather than playing off the wing, Rashford could become a back-up to Robert Lewandowski as a No.9. Lewandowski scored 27 La Liga goals to help Barcelona beat Real Madrid to the title season, but will turn 37 in August.

Another problem is outlined by The Times, who report that United want £40m for Rashford, while Barca are preparing to make an offer of a loan deal. His impressive form for Villa has strengthened the club’s resolve that he is worth £40m – and that could scupper a move to the cash-strapped Catalans.

United still have 68 days left until the transfer deadline on September 1, so could draw out the negotiations. But they will be acutely aware that they could accept a loan deal, on the condition that Barca pay Rashford’s wages – a clause that would save them around £17m over a year.

Rashford has been working on his fitness by himself, but has issued a clear plea to Barca. Speaking while on holiday in Marbella, he was asked by Spanish YouTube channel XBuyer whether he wants to play with Barca wonderkid Lamine Yamal in the future.
"Yeah, sure. Everybody in the world wants to play with the best," the forward replied. "So hopefully, we'll see."
Sky will show at least 215 live Premier League games next season, an increase of up to 100 more.

headline: Manchester United must change transfer approach after £30m blow to solve major problem
body: It is easy to understand why Manchester United were attracted to Liam Delap ahead of the start of this summer's transfer window.
The England Under-21 international was available via a £30million release clause this summer after his first season at Ipswich Town ended in relegation to the Championship.

After joining the Tractor Boys from Manchester City last summer, a £30m release clause was inserted into his contract that would become active if the Suffolk club were to fail to preserve its Premier League status.

Winning just four league games all season, Kieran Mckenna's men had next to no chance of beating the drop. Delap, however, produced some eye-catching moments by plundering 12 Premier League goals in his first season as a regular starter at this level.

As a result, clubs were attracted to him and held discussions about signing him. Despite the best efforts of United, Everton and Newcastle United, Delap chose Chelsea, saying their project was what convinced him to move to Stamford Bridge.

It means United are now having to explore alternative avenues in their search for a No.9. United struggled for goals last season and desperately need to add a focal point to the tip of their attack that can find the back of the net on a regular basis.

The club has already shown plenty of ambition in their efforts to beef up their attacking options, signing Matheus Cunha from Wolves for £62.5m and attempting to get a deal over the line for Brentford's Bryan Mbeumo. The addition of an out-and-out centre-forward, though, remains vital.

United have been linked with a plethora of strikers in recent weeks, both domestically and abroad, but their financial situation will dictate who is a realistic target. At £30m, Delap was an enterprising option, but the Reds would have once again been gambling on potential in their search for a goal-getter.
As respectable as Delap's haul of 12 goals was last season, he is not the finished product. United need somebody who has proven they are a reliable goalscorer over several seasons.

When analysing which of the Premier League's centre-forwards from last season reached double figures, they were all north of 22-years-old with the exception of Delap. Brighton & Hove Albion's Joao Pedro and Chelsea striker Nicolas Jackson were the only strikers to reach double figures in the Premier League that were as young as 23.

Of the 13 recognised strikers that got into double figures for Premier League goals in 2024/25, nine of them were 25 or older. It has been a similar theme in recent seasons, too, highlighting that more experienced strikers find it easier to score goals in the Premier League in comparison to youngsters who are trying to make the grade.

Of course, Manchester City's Erling Haaland is an exception to the rule, scoring 36 times in his debut Premier League campaign at the age of 22 in 2022/23, but the Norwegian is in a league of his own. His freakish record is unlike anything many of us have seen before.

In the sense that Delap would have been an easy target to obtain and sign relatively quickly had others not stuck their nose in, missing out on him is a blow for United, as they have been left trying to solve a search with currently no obvious answer.

However, he was not the striker they needed at this particular juncture, with the club gambling on potential two years ago in the form of Rasmus Hojlund. Signing a striker that little bit older and more experienced is the way forward this summer.

For example, Yoane Wissa (28), Ollie Watkins (29) and Chris Wood (33) were three of the top five scoring strikers in the Premier League last term. United should be attempting to sign someone around the age of 26 or 27 who is about to enter their prime years.

Of course, signing a striker of that profile is going to set United back in terms of spending, but they knew ahead of this summer's transfer window they would have to loosen the purse strings in search of attacking reinforcements.
Any transfer has the capacity to fail or succeed, meaning nothing is a guarantee. But United's Premier League counterparts have proven they will be wiser going for a more experienced goal-getter.

headline: Manchester United PSR position as deadline looms and Bryan Mbuemo deal close amid £120m spend
body: Having missed out on European qualification for 2025/26 last season, it would have been easy to think Manchester United would be handicapped in this summer's transfer window.

Instead, they have adopted an aggressive approach to the start of their biggest window in years. After wrapping up the £62.5million signing of Matheus Cunha earlier this month, they are now close to landing Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo.
After seeing an opening offer of £55m knocked back earlier this month, United submitted a new and improved offer in excess of £60m for the Cameroonian earlier this week.

Barring any late snags or hitches, the 25-year-old, who scored 20 Premier League goals last season, is on course to become their second signing of the summer. Between them, him and Cunha scored 35 league goals in 2024/25.

After seeing their opening offer for Mbeumo rejected, United anticipated they would have to pay a similar fee to the one they did for Cunha. It means that if they get the Mbeumo deal over the line, their spending will go through the £120m mark.

As a result of missing out on European football, United's budget for transfers this summer is not as big as what it would have been had they won the Europa League final. No European football means United are missing out on a minimum of four home games that would have improved cashflow via various matchday revenue streams.

It means more strain will be put on the finances heading into the new financial year. Their latest financial results for the first three months of 2025 revealed a more encouraging picture, despite Sir Jim Ratcliffe, earlier this year, suggesting the club was on course to run out of money by Christmas.

United have slashed their workforce over the last 12 months or so, with around 450 staff being made redundant. As a result, United, earlier this month, played down concerns about breaching UEFA's FFP rules and the Premier League's profit and sustainability rules (PSR).

The end of the 2024/25 financial year for Premier League clubs is Monday, meaning some sides will be under pressure to balance their books. United, however, are not in a position where they are under immediate threat.

An improved start to this calendar year means the club have increased its expected revenue for the financial year ending June 2025 from £660m to £670m. Additionally, United's net cash inflow of £22.3m during the last quarter was an increase of £7.2m from the same quarter last year, highlighting how funds have been freed up.

United know they need to sell players this summer to bring in funds and strengthen Ruben Amorim's squad, and the likes of Jadon Sancho, Marcus Rashford and Antony have been earmarked as priority sales. Alejandro Garnacho is also available at the right price.

If United bank the fees they are looking for for the aforementioned quartet, they will secure somewhere in the region of £150m. No exits are understood to be in the pipeline ahead of Monday, meaning the prospect of them all being sold would see the funds generated from their departures go into the next PSR cycle.

United are understood to want to try and sign Mbeumo ahead of the June 30 deadline and that means the clock is ticking to get the deal over the line. Formally completing a transfer requires various steps and agreements to be put in place and the Brentford attacker is yet to have had a medical.
Ideally, United would like to get him signed and sealed before the end of the Premier League's financial year, but failing to do so would not necessarily be disastrous.

If anything, United's preference to get him in the building ahead of the June 30 deadline highlights they have room to manoeuvre and are not on the brink of landing themselves in hot water with the governing body.

headline: 'Without a doubt' - Man United given five reasons why they should sign Premier League striker
body: Former midfielder Paul Ince would like to see Manchester United turn to Aston Villa star Ollie Watkins in their search for a striker.

United are desperate to recruit a centre-forward this summer and are currently exploring alternative avenues after missing out on Liam Delap, who joined Chelsea from Ipswich Town earlier this month for £30million.

United continue to be linked with the likes of Sporting Lisbon striker Viktor Gyokeres and Napoli's Victor Osimhen, both of who have established themselves as two of the best strikers in Europe, but they are yet to make an official approach for a centre-forward.
It is no secret United will almost certainly have to rely on sales to fund the addition of a No.9, meaning it remains to be seen who they will be able to turn to.

However, if it is possible, Ince, who was speaking ahead of the Manchester #RifeDontMiss Challenge, which is offering the public the opportunity to win £50,000 and break the world record for the longest putt at American Golf Trafford at the beginning of next month, would like to see United swoop for Watkins, who scored 16 Premier League goals last season.

"He has got all of the attributes that you want to go to Manchester United. I am not saying that is going to be the case, but if you look at last season when [Marcus] Rashford went to Villa Park, Watkins got his nose put of joint and didn't really play much.

"There might be something where if he was available, I'd be looking at him for sure. I think Gyokeres has done well in Portugal, and you have got to remember that he scored a lot of goals at Coventry before he went there."
Watkins, 29, joined Villa from Brentford in 2020, has scored 50 Premier League goals since the start of the 2022/23 season, establishing himself as one of the division's most reliable goalscorers.
United, however, have been unable to rely on a reliable striker in recent seasons. They turned to Rasmus Hojlund in August 2023, signing him from Atalanta, but he has struggled to deliver the goods.
Ince, though, has sympathised with the Dane, highlighting how he arrived at Old Trafford as a 20-year-old and was immediately tasked with spearheading United's attack.
"I honestly think Hojlund is one of those where he is still young and he needs someone who can come in and take the weight off his shoulders," Ince added.

"I think he is better as a second striker who might come on later on in a game. When you are asking a young lad to deal with the pressures of Man United, at Old Trafford, at such a young age and to have to keep scoring goals, it puts a lot of pressure on him.
"I think someone like Watkins would take the pressure off him. Maybe they should send Hojlund out on loan for a year and let him score some goals, come back and be confident."

Paul Ince spoke ahead of the Manchester #RifeDontMiss Challenge, celebrating the launch of the new RIFE Black Edition putters. To register for the final qualifier and be in with a chance of winning £50,000, sign up here.

headline: Five Manchester United stars face fight for future ahead of pivotal period
body: Manchester United return to pre-season training next month ahead of the new campaign.

Matheus Cunha will be the headline act as the Reds ramp up preparations for the 2025-26 season. Ruben Amorim's side will hope to improve on their dismal domestic showing last term and travel to America for a summer tour as well as playing in Sweden and at Old Trafford.
United's players will report to Carrington following their summer break in the week commencing July 7. And several stars face make or break periods during the next few weeks.
Manchester United have launched their new home kit for the 2025/26 season with an Adidas shirt paying tribute to Old Trafford.
Fans can order their Men's, Women's and Kid's shirt today.
The arrival of Cunha and expected signing of Bryan Mbuemo mean that the attacking ranks will be bolstered while Amorim is keen to add a central striker.

It means Rasmus Hojlund, who struggled in front of goal last season, is under pressure. The Dane faces losing his place in the side next term if a new striker arrives and he has been linked with an Old Trafford exit.
United splashed an initial £72million on the frontman and haven't had a return on their investment.
But pre-season gives him a chance to build some momentum ahead of the new campaign. If his struggles continue, his United future will be in jeopardy.
Hojlund is not the only one with question marks over his long-term position within the squad.

Andre Onana, who is set to remain as first choice goalkeeper despite an error-strewn 2024-25, needs a stable start to ensure his place doesn't come under further threat, while Luke Shaw must prove he is capable of offering form and fitness after suffering with several injuries in recent years.
He could find a home as a left-sided centre-back in United's set-up but it remains to be seen if he will be able to convince Amorim of his durability.

In midfield, Manuel Ugarte and Kobbie Mainoo have yet to fully convince Amorim. The latter has been in and out of the side through injury and form while he has been used in a variety of positions by the Reds chief, seemingly suggesting that the Portuguese boss hasn't quite settled on how best to utilise the England international.
Ugarte had a mixed debut campaign at Old Trafford and despite working under Amorim earlier in his career, United are looking at potentially adding an athletic midfielder over the summer.
That would place extra pressure on Ugarte and the Uruguay international will hope he can convince his manager of his importance over the coming weeks.
Amorim has shown already that he is not afraid to make big calls, United have several big names who still need to convince.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Bryan Mbeumo latest, Marcus Rashford update, Douglas Luiz 'talks'
body: Hello and welcome to our live Manchester United blog on Friday, June 27.

The Reds are looking to rebuild their squad after completing a deal for Matheus Cunha earlier in the window. United are working hard behind the scenes, with a new striker now said to be the top priority.
Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo looks as though he'll be the next summer signing through the door. The Reds are reportedly set to beat Tottenham Hotspur to his signature.
United are expected to spend big on the Cameroonian international, with the 25-year-old on the brink of a £60million move to Old Trafford in another statement of intent.
However, the Reds know they need to offload several big name stars as part of Ruben Amorim's rebuild. Andre Onana is among those who face an uncertain future at the club.
Meanwhile, Casemiro, Jadon Sancho, Marcus Rashford, and Alejandro Garnacho could also be on the move this summer as part of a major squad overhaul.

The former Borussia Dortmund star, who spent last season on loan at Chelsea, could help United get their hands on a couple of new faces. Sancho has reportedly turned heads in the Serie A, so a swap deal could be on the cards.
Manchester United are 'ready to submit an offer of £34.1million' for Atalanta goalkeeper Marco Carnesecchi and have 'asked for information' on one of his teammates, according to Calcio Mercato.
Carnesecchi impressed for Atalanta last season, keeping 18 clean sheets in all competitions, and could be available for transfer after the departure of Gian Piero Gasperini as head coach.
It's added that while United are prepared to make a £34.1m bid for Carnsecchi, Atalanta want between £38.4m and £42.6m to sanction the 24-year-old's exit in the summer transfer window.
As well as Carnesecchi, it appears that United remain keen on a deal for long-term target Ederson. The Reds have asked for more information on the Brazilian's situation at Old Trafford.
It is easy to understand why Manchester United were attracted to Liam Delap ahead of the start of this summer's transfer window.
The England Under-21 international was available via a £30million release clause this summer after his first season at Ipswich Town ended in relegation to the Championship.

After joining the Tractor Boys from Manchester City last summer, a £30m release clause was inserted into his contract that would become active if the Suffolk club were to fail to preserve its Premier League status.
